Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Enabling Application-Level Performance Predictability in Public Clouds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
State-of-the-art resource sharing mechanisms in today's datacenters and compute clouds are agnostic to application-level performance requirements, resulting in unpredictable performance. This is especially true for the network. Unlike, CPU, memory, or disk, cloud operators do not provide any guarantees for the network. Many tenants rely on over-provisioning and static allocation for performance isolation, which results in low utilization and increased cost and environmental impacts. This project aims to build a set of solutions to achieve short- and long-term performance predictability with high resource utilization. The goal is to enable coexisting applications from different tenants to meet a variety of performance objectives including obtaining timely responses and minimizing variance of successive responses, while adhering to organizational hierarchies of individual tenants. The key technical challenges in this project include developing short- and long-term resource allocation algorithms, accurate demand estimation, as well as fast and efficient enforcement, all of which are compounded by the multi-resource and shared nature of the network. Two key techniques guide the proposed work: (i) temporal scheduling ensures predictable performance through short- and long-term performance isolation, and (ii) spatial placement ensures higher utilization through initial placement and periodic migration of tenants' virtual machines.


Predictable, efficient data analytics will have significant socio-economic ramifications. It will also enable mission-critical applications, e.g., anomaly detection, fraud protection, autonomous vehicles, and robotics-- that require a highly consistent and reliable level of performance to coexist with the less sensitive ones. Algorithms and software from the project will be incorporated into existing open-source big data stacks for public reuse. By leveraging ongoing relationships with the industry, artifacts from this project will be converted from research into practice in a fast manner. The project has significant educational and outreach components, which include introducing new courses at both graduate and undergraduate levels based on the outcomes of this project as well as arranging cloud computing boot camps aimed at students from high schools and involving women and under-represented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to build a set of solutions to achieve short- and long-term performance predictability with high resource utilization. The goal is to enable coexisting applications from different tenants to meet a variety of performance objectives including obtaining timely responses and minimizing variance of successive responses, while adhering to organizational hierarchies of individual tenants. Two key techniques guide the research in this project: (i) temporal scheduling ensures predictable performance through short- and long-term performance isolation, and (ii) spatial placement ensures higher utilization through initial placement and periodic migration of tenants' virtual machines. 

During the project, we have conducted research in the following directions towards the major goals of the project. First, we have worked on the problem of allocating GPUs and CPUs across multiple applications. We have developed a predictor about the performance of applications on CPUs vs GPUs, and built a scheduler based on these predictions. Our work appeared in Eurosys 2020 as a full paper. 

Second, we have worked on the online resource provisioning with information uncertainty, a key challenge to enabling performance predictability. While there have been a wide variety of online algorithms (e.g. Receding Horizon Control, Online Balanced Descent) designed, it is hard for cloud operators to pick the right algorithm. In particular, these algorithms vary greatly on their usage of predictions and performance guarantees. We have developed automatic algorithm selection in real time. This work has been published in ACM Sigmetrics 2019. We further studied how to use change point detection to react promptly to sudden changes. This work has been published in the 53rd Annual Conference on Information Sciences and Systems (CISS) 2019.  

We further applied the online optimization framework to edge computing and virtual network functions (VNFs). The results have been presented in ICPP 2019, INFOCOM 2020 (best paper award), IWQoS 2020, and IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing. We have developed resource allocation schemes for both (long-term) fairness and (short-term) performance by proposing Bounded Priority Fairness (BPF). We are currently working with IBM to deploy the algorithms in the IBM Watson AI/ML system. 

The PI has designed and is currently teaching the course AMS 560 "Big data systems, algorithms and networks" annually at Stony Brook University. Enrolled students include PhD and master students from Applied Math, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering. During the past four years, with the support of this project, we have significantly improved the course materials and the enrollment has increased from 12 to the class capacity. Students enthusiastically embrace this course, demonstrated by the high teaching evaluations and the PI got "Excellence in Teaching" award every year.

Our work has been recognized by the following awards. (1) Our paper "Reducing the Service Function Chain Backup Cost over the Edge and Cloud by a Self-adapting Scheme" won Best Paper Award at INFOCOM 2020. (2) The PI was awarded IBM 2020 Global University Program Academic Award (formerly known as IBM Faculty Award). (3) My PhD student won the Woo Jong Kim Dissertation Award. (4) My high school student was named National semifinalist (scholar) of the Regeneron Science Talent Search.

This project has provided training for several PhD students and several master, undergraduate, and high school students. They have been working on the research project and made significant contributions. The PI holds weekly research meetings with the students. This has provided an opportunity for our students to present and discuss their research ideas. The meetings also occasionally involve project presentations from students. The presentations, though informal, provide useful feedback to the students and will help to improve their oral communication skills. The students involved in this project gained hands-on experience setting up experiments at CloudLab and Chameleon cloud, both publicly-available platforms. We also obtained GPU-equipped machines from another NSF-funded CRI grant we received with Rutgers University.
